Sentence: Dear Madam, Please accept this letter as my considered opinion to the questions posed under your Terms of Reference received by myself on [7 May 2008] with respect to S197(1)(b) of the Securities and Futures Act (chapter 289, 2002 Revised Edition).
Glossary and Facts provided to myself and used in this report:

AIM? or ?the Company? means Advanced Integrated Manufacturing Corp Ltd an electronics manufacturing services provider, specializing in medium and high-end application for aerospace-avionics, medical, life sciences, data storage, semi-conductor and fiber optics industries and which was listed on the SGX main board on 26 May 2005 with an initial public offering price of $0.20; b. ?
Teo? shall mean Mrs. Teo Siew Ling, the wife of Vincent; c.
Intraday Price? means the change in the price between the day?s opening price and the day?s closing price during the Relevant Period.
For example on the 27/3/2006 the opening price of the Shares was 33 cents and the closing price was 36 cents.
The Intraday price was thus 3 cents.
Note the opening 12 price is not necessarily the same as the previous day?s closing price.
The closing price of the 26/3/2006 was 32.5 cents.
d. ?Market Days? means the days on which the Singapore Stock Exchange was open for trading;
Relevant Period? means the 15 February 2006 and 31 October 2006 inclusive; f. ?
SESMANU? means the SES Manufacturing Index; g. ?SFA? means Securities and Futures Act (chapter 289, 2002 Revised Edition);
SGX? shall mean the Singapore Exchanged Limited and its subsidiaries the Singapore Stock Exchange and the Singapore International Monetary Exchange; i. ?Share(s)? or ?
AIM Shares? means the ordinary, issued and fully paid shares of AIM and which are listed on the SGX;
j. ?STI? means the Straits Times Index;
Vincent? shall mean Dr. Vincent Tan Kim Yong or Vincent Tan Kim Yong and Teo Siew Ling.
Thus when the report speaks of Vincent?s action it means either the action of Vincent Tan Kim Yong solely or the actions of Vincent Tan Kim Yong and Teo Siew Ling jointly.
74 Days? means the 74 days during the Relevant Period on which Vincent executed a trade; m. One
folder of information and further supplementary data by way of e-mail and as listed in Appendix 1.
Having regard to the prevailing market conditions, a.
What appearance did the orders and trades conducted by Vincent create, or were likely to create, with respect to the market for AIM shares?
In particular, did the orders and trades by Vincent create, or were likely to create, a false or misleading appearance with respect to the market for AIM shares?
What appearance did the orders and trades conducted by Vincent create, or were likely to create, with respect to the price of AIM shares?
In particular, did the orders and trades by Vincent create, or were likely to create, a false or misleading appearance with respect to the price of AIM shares?

Should you be of the opinion that the orders and trades by Vincent had affected the market for and/or price of AIM shares in any way, please give your opinion on whether it could be inferred that the orders and trades were intentionally carried out to cause such an appearance or effect, and if so, the basis of this inference.
In the above analysis, you may assume that the orders and trades in Teo Siew Ling?s securities trading account were conducted by Vincent.
All my expert opinions rely on one significant assumption - that the trading efficiency of the Singapore Stock Market is best described by the ?semi-strong form? market efficiency theory.
This market theory states that equity markets are generally efficient but are not always or wholly efficient.

There are rival theories and they include: a ?strong form? theory that postulates that stock markets are wholly efficient; and a ?weak form? theory that postulates that stock markets are wholly inefficient.
In a wholly efficient market (?strong form?) all information is known and thus no action undertaken by any person can distort or manipulate the market.
In a wholly inefficient market (?weak form?) very little information is available to, or known by, investors.
Thus all actions distort the market significantly.
It is my experience that most of my fellow professionals in the finance industry adhere to the semi-strong form market efficiency assumption.
This expert opinion has been prepared in the knowledge that it may be used in a court of law.

Not withstanding the fact that this expert opinion was requested by the Commercial Affairs Department, I confirm that this expert opinion is independent in the sense that the opinions it sets forth have not been influenced by the Commercial Affairs Department and has been prepared to assist the Court rather than to support the case before me.
I further confirm that I understand my duties as an expert witness to the Court and that I have complied with such duties.

AIM Shares only traded on 146 days out of the 185 available days, meaning on 39 Market Days during the Relevant Period there were no trades in AIM Shares.

The first announcement on 19 January 2006 was with respect to the acquisition of the intellectual property rights to the following lancet assembly, safety syringe, safety heel stick & safety scalpel.
In an announcement dated 20 January 2006 AIM further announced it was unable to judge the likely impact of this acquisition as the inventions were new.

Further, and given that AIM?s main products are avionics for the aerospace industry it is difficult to see why investors would get very excited by ASIM acquiring a mass market low per unit value medical device.
The second announcement on the 15 February 2006 is with respect to the full year 2005 earnings.
On an pro-forma adjusted basis the net profit announced was S$8.5 million down from FY2004?s S$12.1 million.
It is also difficult to see why investors would greet such a decline warmly.
There were only two notable announcements in the 8 weeks leading up to 10 November 2006 and the start of the AIM Share price decline.

Market for the Securities 16 A market can be defined in several ways.
For the purposes of this report I have defined a market as a process where securities are bought and sold by various parties or persons.
Thus, and at its most basic, a market is simply the sum of the price at which quantities of a security has been traded.
Market = sum (price * volume traded)

Label: Reason
Sentence: The pattern of Vincent?s trades suggests to me the valuation of AIM may not have been the only or even the primary factor motivating him.
Any investor, even a major shareholder, will want to maximize their profit on their investment.
Thus they would try to keep their cost of purchases low.

Label: Event
Sentence: For instance: a. He did not spread his trades but concentrated them between the 15 February 2006 and 31 March 2006 and as shown in the chart below.
Such a concentration of buying could and did have dramatic effects.

Label: Attribute

Label: Reason
Sentence: As a result the average cost that Vincent paid would have been higher than one paid by a prudent investor seeking to maximize returns
b. Vincent started buying the Shares, after having made no trades between the 3 April 2006 and the 15 May 2006, on the 16 May 2006.

Sentence: May 2006 and 14 June 2006, the STI and the SESMANU declined by 9% and 14%.

Label: Event
Sentence: Vincent?s later purchases at around 33 cents and 33.5 cents, given the market correction, do not.

Label: Reason
Sentence: It is difficult to understand why Vincent did not spread his buying over more days to achieve lower buying costs.

Label: Reason
Sentence: An investor seeking to minimize cost: would not bias his trades towards the afternoon session but would spread his trades evenly throughout the day.

Label: Reason
Sentence: This is because to do so would result in afternoon session and closing price rising and thus increasing the cost for the following day?s purchases.
As evidenced in Vincent's Buying Pattern, Vincent biased his trades towards the afternoon and pre-close trading sessions.

Label: Reason
Sentence: An investor seeking to minimize cost would not aggressively seek to execute the last trade or aggressively trade in the pre-close.

Label: Reason
Sentence: This is because to do so would result in the closing price rising and thus increasing the cost for the following day?s purchases.

Label: Reason
Sentence: Point 14 clearly shows that by biasing his trades towards the afternoon session and aggressively seeking to execute the last trade and trade in the pre-close, Vincent significantly increased his pricing risk (the spread was larger) and paid more.

Label: Reason
Sentence: I believe that I have demonstrated in Points 5 to 20 that Vincent?s actions significantly impacted the price of, the traded volume of and thus the market for the Shares.

Label: Reason

Label: Reason
Sentence: Having done so, I find it difficult to escape the conclusion that Vincent intended to affect the price of AIM Shares.

Label: Reason
Sentence: Vincent knew or should have known that his trading pattern would significant impact the price of AIM Shares.

Label: Reason
Sentence: Vincent knew or should have known that his actions would cause the price of AIM Shares to rise significantly thereby creating a misleading appearance in the price of AIM Shares.

Dear Madam, Please accept this letter as my considered opinion to the questions posed under your Terms of Reference received by myself on the 28 October 2004, with respect to $97 of the Securities Industry Act
Leong means Leong Yew Cheong, a former Executive Vice?Chairman and Director of Autron;
It was originally listed on the ASX as Pacific Communications Holdings Ltd.
It changed to its current name on 5 July 2000 to reflect both a change in business and in control.
On the 3 May 2001, Autron was listed by way of a dual listing on the @ SGX.
At 30 June 2003, the total number of Autron Shares outstanding was 685,902,302.
At 30 June 2004, the total number of Autron Shares cutstanding was 693,373,890.
At 30 June 2003, there were no options or warrants outstanding.
At 30 June 2004, there were 213,610,436 options outstanding that could be converted 213,610,436 shares for S$0.18 each and these options expire on 3 June 2007;
One CD containing all the trades of Autron during the Relevant Period; and d. Announcements and press releases during the Relevant Period.

In my opinion, did any of the orders or transactions, or any combination of © the orders or transactions executed in the accounts of Tan and Yew at the Pre? Close, as shown in Appendix 8 and 9 respectively, create or cause to be created or is calculated to create, a false or misleading appearance with respect to the market for, or the price of, Autron Corporation Limited shares, for the period from 1 April 2002 to 30 September 2002.
If so, please give details of how this had happened and the extent to which this had happened.

In my opinion, did any of the orders or transactions, or any combination of the orders or transactions executed in the accounts of Tan and Yew at the Pre? Close, as shown in Appendix 8 and 9 respectively, create or is intended to create or likely to create, a false or misleading appearance with respect to the market for, or the price of, Autron Corporation Limited shares, for the period from 1 October 2002 to 30 April 2003.
If so, please give details of how this had happened and the extent to which this had happened.
For the purposes of my analysis, I may wish to consider: a. Tan and Yew as acting and controlled as one by Leong; b.
That Leong sought Ng Geok Eng?s help to support the Share price and thus knew or should have known that Ng and his group traded Autron Shares; and
The prevailing market conditions or any other factors that may cause or contribute to the existing market and price conditions of Autron Corporation Limited shares during the Relevant Period.
The Terms of Reference, namely paragraphs 3(a) and 4(a), divides the Relevant Period into two parts.
The reason for the division is that the SFA superseded the SIA with effect on 1 October 2002.
For analytical purposes it makes more sense to treat the Relevant Period as a continuous period.
Accordingly and for the purposes of this letter I have treated, and reviewed, the whole of the Relevant Period as a continuous period.
Close during the Relevant Period may not have been the only time the Leong Group traded the Shares of Autron.
No review of such trading prior or subsequent to the Relevant Period was undertaken.
I have been asked to comment on "orders or transactions, or any combination of the orders or transactions executed" in the accounts of the Leong Group during the Pre? Close.
A period of 6 minutes after the market closes at 1700 hours (namely 1700 to 1706 hours) where trades may still take place through the SGX to help clear unexecuted trades.
These include trades placed before 1700 hours but may include trades placed after 1700 hours.

Close Routine consists of 2 parts, namely a pre?Close period (1700 to 1705 hours) where orders can be placed or withdrawn and a Non?Cancel period (1705 to 1706 hours) where no orders may be placed or withdrawn.
Cancel period the matching is done by way of a set methodology.
The SGX adds all the buy orders up to the highest price and all the sell orders to the lowest price.
If there are no overlaps there is no match.
If there is an overlap the matches take place.

The equilibrium or closing price is the price with the largest trade or, if this could apply to several prices, will then depend on whether the whole of the buying pressure exceeds the whole of the selling pressure or vice versa.
If buying pressure exceeds selling pressure, then the equilibrium or closing price shall be the highest traded price.
If selling pressure exceeds buying pressure, then the equilibrium or closing price shall be the lowest traded price.
In the example below provided by the SGX, the match can occur at $0.30, $0.305 or $0.31.
As buying pressure exceeds selling pressure, the equilibrium and closing price is deemed to be $$0.31.
Close and the use of the equivalent price method of setting the closing price is to make it difficult for a person to manipulate closing prices with a single transaction.
Close and the equivalent price method cannot prevent a determined person(s) from creating buying or selling pressure thereby affecting the price, volume or market of a security.

I have been asked to comment on whether the Leong Group?s transactions, during the Relevant Period "create or cause to create or is calculated to create, a false or misleading appearance with respect to the market for, or the price of the Shares.
To my mind "create or cause to create or is calculated to create" requires an action of some force or consequence.
Meaning that the Leong Group would have to have undertaken some action(s) or transaction(s) of some substance that could affect the price and/or traded volume of the Shares.
The Leong Group traded on 15 days at the Pre?Close during the Relevant Period.
Close but overall was not very active at the Pre?Close during the Relevant Period.

A period of 6 minutes after the market closes at 1700 hours (namely 1700 to 1706 hours) where trades may still take place through the SGX to help clear unexecuted trades.
These include trades placed before 1700 hours but may include trades placed after 1700 hours.

Close Routine consists of 2 parts, namely a pre?Close period (1700 to 1705 hours) where orders can be placed or withdrawn and a Non?Cancel period (1705 to 1706 hours) where no orders may be placed or withdrawn.
During the Non?Cancel period, orders are matched.
Cancel period the matching is done by way of a set methodology.
The SGX adds all the buy orders up to the highest price and all the sell orders to the lowest price.
If there are no overlaps there is no match.
If there is an overlap the matches take place.

The equilibrium or closing price is the price with the largest trade or, if this could apply to several prices, will then depend on whether the whole of the buying pressure exceeds the whole of the selling pressure or vice versa.
If buying pressure exceeds selling pressure, then the equilibrium or closing price shall be the highest traded price.
If selling pressure 3 of 35Privae & Confidential ACH Investments Pte Ltd DRAFT exceeds buying pressure, then the equilibrium or closing price shall be the lowest traded price.
In the example below provided by the SGX, the match can occur at $0.30, $0.305 or $0.31.
As buying pressure exceeds selling pressure, the equilibrium and closing price is deemed to be $$0.31.
Table 1: SGX example of the equilibrium price when buying pressure exceeds selling pressure
Close and the use of the equivalent price method of setting the closing price is to make it difficult for a person to manipulate closing prices with a single transaction.
Close and the equivalent price method cannot prevent a determined person(s) from creating buying or selling pressure thereby affecting the price, volume or market of a security.

Expert Witness Statement as per instruction dated 21 May 2003 I refer to your request for an independent assessment of the material relating to a "suspected breach of Section 97(1)" of the Singapore Securities Industry Act.
I note it involves trading in the securities of Chartered Semiconductor Manufacturing Limited (hereafter CHART) for 31 May 2000.
In particular, I will address whether, in my opinion, the nominated company may have been the subject of trading behaviour likely to cause concern under section 97 (1) of the Securities Industry Act.

More specifically whether there is prima facie evidence of orders/trades being placed/executed in a way that created, or was intended or was likely to create, a false or misleading appearance with respect to the market for, or the price of, the relevant security.
Consistent with your instructions, in section one I set out my expertise.
In section two, I outline issues to do with the data.
In section three, I set forth a practical method for identifying potential pricemanipulation at the close of trading.
In section four I provide the results of my analysis, while in section five, I provide my overall conclusions.
It is important for the purpose of analysis that both parties are referring to the same trading incidents and that the data for each trading incident is identical for both parties.
I secured the data for my analysis independent of the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD).
The data comes via the Singapore Exchange (SGX).

It covers the period three ? These include the Hong Kong Exchanges, the Securities and Futures Commission of Hong Kong, the Singapore Exchanges, the Singapore Monetary Authority, the Moscow Inter?bank Currency Exchange, The Russian Central Bank, the Swedish Stock Exchange, the Copenhagen Stock Exchange, the Oslo Stock Exchange, the Jakarta Stock Exchange, the Iceland Stock Exchange and the New Zealand Stock Exchange.

SGX secures the full order book data via the SGX market surveillance department and all my statements are premised on the assumption that the data procedures of SGX Surveillance do not change the underlying data and that we have access to the same order and trade data.
I do not have any evidence that SGX surveillance produce inaccurate data.

I have checked attributes of the data, in particular total turnover against an independent source, namely Bloomberg, and nothing material has come to light that would suggest that the data cannot be used for the purpose of identifying prima facie market manipulation.
book data enables me to reconstruct any nanosecond of trade history in using the SMARTS software.
Using the SMARTS module REPLAY, I can replay the market for CHART for any time during the analysis period.
I am happy to use this technology in any hearing on this matter.
The second data set contained all information announcements for a week either side of 31 May 2000.
Under the listing rules of the SGX, all information emanating from listed compamies is required to be released through the SGX?s MASNET first.
Further by the rules of continuous disclosure all information material to the price of a security must be released immediately.

These two rules means that for the purpose of looking for value relevant information (to understand why prices may have moved) we should be able to rely on the information obtained from MASNET which has been supplied by the CAD. 3.0 How to Identify Prima Facie Market Manipulation Market manipulation is to be distinguished from other types of aberrant trader behaviour such as insider trading or front?running.

In brief, market manipulation occurs where the free market forces of demand and supply are interrupted by a party or parties (acting in conjunction) who are intent on influencing the price of the security in the absence of any value relevant information.
The key difference between insider trading and market manipulation is that in the case of the former, value relevant information exists but is hidden from the market.
In the case of the latter there is no value relevant information.
Because it is widely accepted that prices are information revealing" there is an incentive for some parties to trade as if they were privy to information in order to induce others to trade °
Because information is a decaying product, holders of value relevant information must use it or lose it.
However, in the process of using it, that is, trading, the information becomes impounded in price.
With respect to price there are generally two types of manipulation.
Manipulation at the close and manipulation involving related parties.
Manipulation at the close usually takes the form of limited trading activity, but with any market participant, to affect the price at the close of trading? .

Conducting such transactions as near as possible to the close of trading limits the amount of trading required to affect price, and in turn, the loss when the stock reverts to its normal price in subsequent trading periods".
The latter type of manipulation usually involves sustained trading volume over longer periods but with related parties.

While there is no indisputable method for determining what does or does not constitute trading or order placement likely to cause a false or misleading appearance, my work with 9 national exchanges and 3 national regulators, suggests that there are 3 practical heuristics that can be used to help establish whether trading behaviour is potentially manipulative at the close in a relevant sense for the purposes of section 97 (1) of the Securities Industry Act. The first element is to establish that trading activity leads to a price that is statistically unusual when judged against trades over a benchmark period.

Label: Reason
Sentence: As a practical rule, this involves identifying trades that are in the top 1% of prices over a benchmark period, usually 1 month prior and subsequent to the event.
Such trades would qualify for treatment as statistically unusual, warranting a search for value creating information.
If none is to be found then the likelihood is market manipulation.

Label: Reason
Sentence: A second element for identifying potentially manipulative behaviour at the close is to identify trades that break through the available best bid/ask to establish new best bid/asks.
The more price steps that are broken through in the absence of information the greater the likelihood of manipulation.
In the case of the SGX 5.00pm or 5.06pm if the match is used.

Label: Reason
Sentence: A third element for identifying potentially manipulative behaviour at the close is to identify trading circumstances that push the price to a level that is not sustained when the market re? opens, excluding the trading activity of the party suspected of manipulation.

In my opinion, the presence of all three elements referred to above are required before one can make the claim that trading is likely to be manipulative in a relevant sense for the purposes of section 97 (1) of the Securities Industry Act (i.e. that it created, or caused to be created or was calculated to create, a false or misleading appearance with respect to the market for, or the price of, the relevant securities).

For practical purposes I take the phrase "to create a false and misleading appearance" to mean that the price of the security at the close did not reflect the broader markets? view of the underlying value of the securities.

As a practical matter this is determined by identifying the disproportionate influence of one investor at the close coupled with what a reasonable person might describe as a highly unusual trading circumstance.
The latter is determined by reference first to a rise in the price of a security at the end of a trading session and a subsequent price reversal at the beginning of the next trading session.

To address this issue, I have analysed how unusual the traded price is with reference to all prices over the month before and after the trading in question" and the volume?weighted average price (VWAP) from the start of the trading day to immediately prior to the unusual trading behaviour.

In this case although the trading volume seems large, it is worth noting that given where the price ended up had this been tried earlier in the day, it would almost certainly have cost significantly more to keep at the price at these levels.

There is reasoned argument to suggest that this should be extended to a month either side of the suspicious trading however I have chosen to use the one month period prior to trading as choosing a prior trading period is the most common approach currently in use.
The second element for deciding whether an order strategy is manipulative is to identify whether the order behaviour led to the trade breaking through a best bid/ask to establish new bids and asks.

Label: Reason
Sentence: In my opinion, the trading activity must as a minimum break through the best bid/ask in order to be regarded as potentially manipulative.

Label: Reason

Label: Reason

Proprietary trading involves intra?day trading by remisiers and dealers representatives on behalf of their broking house which acts as a principal and not an agent in the transaction with the sole purpose of making an absolute gain from the more volatile movements in a stock during the trading day.

Gains from proprietary trading less transactions costs, which in the case of G K Goh is fixed at $$400.00 per stock, are shared equally between the proprietary trader and G K Goh while tosses are only borne by the proprietary trader.
All positions must be closed within the same trading day,
market transactions are permitted with the bulk of the trades being contra? positions.
Collateral or a banker?s guarantee is provided by the proprietary trader to the stock broking company, in this case G K Goh.
The usual practice is for a bankers? guarantee of $$50,000/? for a trading limit of S$S5mn.

Given the significant risks on the part of the proprietary trader, ie that he has to bear all losses and share half the profits, they usually focus their trading activity on stocks with high "beta?"s which is a measure of volatility usually against the market index.

In the case of Dayen since its listing and up till April 24, 2002, its volatility relative to the Straits Times Industrial Index was high at more than 10.64 times (bearing in mind that this was just two weeks after listing there may not be enough data points for an accurate calculation but the figure is a good indication of its volatility at that time).

The announcement by the SGX on April 24, 2002 that there was no evidence that the Dayen stock was cornered after one week of investigations revived trading interest in the stock from both proprietary and contra traders.

On April 24, 2002, Dayen shares started trading at S$0.555, reached an intra?day high of $$0.68 before closing at $$0.655, for a rise of $0.115 or +20.7%.

Take-over offers of shares of companies listed on the Singapore Exchange are governed by rules found in the Singapore Code on Take-overs and Mergers (?the Code?, the version in force was that dated 15 March 2007).

When a person (or persons acting in concert with him) a) holding less than 30% of the voting rights acquires additional shares which results in him owning 30% or more of the voting rights, or b) holding more than 30% voting rights but less than 50% acquires, in any 6 months period, additional shares carrying more than 1% of the voting rights, he is obliged to extend a general offer (?GO?) to all shareholders.
This is referred to as a mandatory GO and comes under Rule 14.1.
A mandatory GO must be paid in cash, and the offer price must not be less than the highest price paid by the offeror (or persons acting in concert) during the offer period and 6 months preceding it.
On the other hand, a person who has not incurred an obligation to make a mandatory GO may choose to make a voluntary offer.
In that case, he has to abide by Rule 15.1 of the Code on voluntary GOs.

A voluntary GO can be paid in cash or securities or both, and the offer price must not be less than the highest price paid by the offeror (or his concert parties) during the offer period and 3 months preceding it.
Whether a GO is mandatory or voluntary, it is conditional on the offeror receiving acceptances of more than 50% of the voting rights, after which the offer becomes unconditional.
This is to ensure that the successful offeror will ultimately have control (i.e. more than 50%) of the Company after the take-over exercise.

If the amount of acceptances is such that the Offeror?s total shareholdings in Jade shares, after the Offer 15 closes, will be less than 50% the Offer is considered to have failed and the acceptances will be treated as cancelled.

For both the mandatory and voluntary GO, Rule 3.5 of the Code requires a confirmation to be made upfront by an appropriate third-party (eg. a bank or financial adviser) that the offeror has sufficient financial resources to settle in full in the event that all acceptances of the offer take place.
This is an important requirement to ensure that the GO will not fail because of a lack of funding.
Most mandatory GOs are launched with the intention of gaining majority control of the listed company.
As such, the offer price is normally set at a level above the prevailing market price of the share to encourage a higher level of acceptance by existing shareholders.
However, there are some mandatory GOs that are carried out not because the offerors wanted majority control.
It could be a simple case of someone acquiring additional shares as a result of which Rule 14.1 of the Code is triggered, requiring the person to make a mandatory GO.
An example of this would be the opportunistic acquisition, say, of a block of shares put on the market (by a fund manager or strategic investor, say).

Let?s say the transacted price is at or near the prevailing market price of the share and the buyer (whether new or an existing shareholder) has no intention of gaining majority control (as he is happy with the current management, say), then the offer price he would set for this mandatory GO is likely to be low (although not lower than his purchase price).
With a low offer price, acceptances would likely be low.
On the other hand, voluntary GOs are carried out not compelled by the requirements of the Code but ?voluntarily? by someone wishing to gain majority control of the listed company.
An example of this is the voluntary conditional cash offer by APPL for Jade Technology Holdings Ltd (?Jade?).
In fact, some voluntary GOs are launched by existing substantial/majority shareholders with the intention of de-listing the company and taking it private.

As the objective of voluntary GOs is to ultimately have majority (or even 100%) control of the listed company, the offer price is usually set significantly above the prevailing market price of the share so that existing shareholders will find it attractive and hence accept the offer.
Offer was priced at a premium of 15.4% over the last transacted price of $0.195 on 13 February 2008 and 17.3% above the 3-month volume weighted price of Jade shares.
It was also a hefty 59.1% premium over the 1-month volume weighed price of Jade shares and 1,096.8% premium over the net tangible asset per share.
The offer price of $.225 would therefore be considered attractive.
Acceptances for the Offer would be expected to be high.

Since it was announced in the Offer document that APLL already owned around 46.54% of Jade shares, the chances of APLL gaining 50% or more of the voting rights of the Company would also be high, which would likely make the Offer turn unconditional.

Label: Attribute
Feature: Index
Sentence: As a third party financial adviser or bank (OCBC in this case) confirmed that the offeror had the financial resources to cover all acceptances in full, market participants would, therefore, expect that, if they could not sell Jade shares at a higher price in the market, they would be able to sell them at $0.225 to the Offeror by accepting the Offer.

Offer for Jade shares was announced on 18 February 2008.

Label: Attribute

Label: Attribute

For example, if a person bought 100,000 Jade shares at $0.195 and subsequently accepted the Offer, he could make a profit of around $3,000, less the trading costs of his purchase (there is no cost involved in accepting the Offer).

In fact, even if the price of Jade shares were to rise to $0.220 it would still be profitable for someone to buy them and sell them to the Offeror at the offer price of $0.225, as the cost of his purchase would only be around slightly less than $0.001 per share (an estimate based on 100,000 Jade shares purchased, and assuming a brokerage charge of around 0.375% for such trades and the usual clearing and miscellaneous fees and GST).

There is no surprise that a voluntary conditional cash offer priced at a significant premium over the prevailing market price of a share (like the APLL?s Offer), would likely cause the share price of the listed entity to rise to that of the offer price (or very close to it).

In fact, among all the information released by companies, an attractively priced voluntary conditional cash offer always rank as one of the easiest for market participants to understand and interpret, and that is, that the traded price of the share will rise towards the offer price.
As explained earlier, this is because buyers would enter the market to buy the Jade shares for profit as long as the prevailing market price is lower than the Offer price.
In addition, if there is a significant drop in the share price below that of the Offer price during the offer period, one would expect the Offeror (and its concert parties) to pick up those shares.
This would boost their holding of Jade shares and further consolidate their position and at the same time reduce their overall acquisition cost.
Therefore, the price increase of Jade shares was likely to be maintained or supported during the entire offer period.

Importance of Having Sufficient Financial Resources 75.

To ensure that a take-over offer will not fail because of a lack of funds, Rule 3.5 of the Code states that ?Where the offer is for cash or involves an element of cash, the 27 announcement of an offer should include an unconditional confirmation by the financial adviser or by another appropriate third party that the offeror has sufficient financial resources available to satisfy full acceptance of the offer.
This is an important assurance to shareholders that whoever accepts the offer will be paid in full by the Offeror.

This would be an important consideration for not only existing shareholders who look forward to accepting the offer but also new buyers of the offeree?s shares, especially those who had bought the shares with a view to selling them subsequently to the Offeror (by accepting the Offer) for profit, in the knowledge that they would be able to ?square off? their positions without fear of a default in payment.
In the case of APLL?s Offer, this confirmation was provided by OCBC, a reputable bank in Singapore.
This would add a level of comfort to shareholders and market participants to the Offer and enhance the credibility of APLL.
As the Offer was conditional upon APLL obtaining 50% or more of the voting rights in Jade, acceptances would be honored only when this threshold was reached.
In the event that APLL failed to gain the 50% or more voting rights in Jade after the close of the Offer period, then the Offer would be deemed withdrawn and all acceptances cancelled.
But as mentioned earlier, APLL?s Offer was considered attractive and hence the probability of the threshold being crossed would be high.
What would happen if it subsequently turned out that APLL did not have sufficient financial resources to implement the Offer for Jade shares in full?
If that was the case, APLL would not have available funds to pay for all acceptances of Jade shares.
This would mean that the Offer or the whole take-over exercise would be at risk of failing.
Market participants would want to know the reason for the sudden change in APLL?s financial position and if the Offer would be called off.
The uncertainty would be very bad for the market.
Existing shareholders looking forward to accepting the Offer 28 would now be confused and uncertain if their acceptances would be honored.

Buyers of Jade shares, especially those intending to make a profit by subsequently selling the shares back to APLL (by accepting the Offer), would be shocked and uncertain if they would be able to ?square off? their long positions.
The usual reaction to such uncertainty would be to quickly dispose of their shares in the market to avoid a loss or minimize loss.
The resulting selling pressure would rapidly depress the price of Jade shares.
Even the common investor would react negatively by selling their holding of Jade shares irrespective of whether they bought them for quick profit or based on fundamentals.
This is because the revelation of APLL?s lack of financial resources would mean that the financial position of APLL had weakened suddenly and significantly, and that the Offer might be in jeopardy.
There would not only be doubts cast on the credibility of APLL and Dr Anthony Soh but also ultimately on Jade.

In addition, common investors would know that the resulting heavy selling of Jade shares would depress the price of Jade shares significantly, possibly pushing it back to its pre-Offer level or even lower.
A common investor would not be likely to sit still and do nothing under such circumstances.
Instead, they would likely adopt the ?play-it-safe? attitude by taking the ?sell first and find out later? approach.
Also, potential buyers would likely hold back their purchases.
This would depress the price of Jade shares even further.
Showing How the Withdrawal of APLL?s Offer Had Affected the Price of Jade Shares 81.

The actual effect on the price of Jade shares after the revelation of the ?insufficient financial resources information? could be seen from the trading of Jade shares on 7 April 2008, the first trading day after the announced withdrawal of the Offer on 5 April 2008 (6 April 2008 being a weekend).

According to the announcement (a copy is attached as Appendix H), APLL was required, by reason of events relating to Opes, to have additional financial resources to satisfy full acceptances of the Offer.

But due to the sudden and unexpected turn of events, APLL was not able to obtain an unconditional confirmation from an appropriate third party that there were available funds to satisfy full acceptances of the Offer.
As a result, the Offer was withdrawn.

As the GMSLA had provided for the re-delivery of the Jade shares back to APLL if the loan was repaid, questions would be asked if APLL could come up with the funds within a reasonable time to repay Opes and avoid any force-selling.
Further, if APLL could not repay the loan, then those Jade shares would likely be force-sold by Opes? creditors.
If that happened, there would not be any Jade shares left for re-delivery even if, at a later date, APLL could find the funds for repayment.
To a common investor who did not have sight of the GMSLA, the above possible events may effectively reduce the percentage shareholding that APLL had in Jade shares.
The above concerns of a common investor would be even greater if he knew of the contents of the GMSLA.
According to the GMSLA, the beneficial ownership of the 300,050,000 Jade shares was transferred to Opes when the cash or loan proceeds were given to APLL.
So, those 300,050,000 Jade shares did not actually belong to APLL anymore once the GMSLA was signed and cash paid to APLL.
The beneficial ownership of those Jade shares would no longer be APLL
and that would likewise reduce the percentage of shareholding that APLL had of Jade shares.

The Daily Listing of Orders and Trades in Keda shares provided by SGX made it possible to re?construct, chronologically, how John and Lee used their respective securities accounts with Phillip Securities and Lim & Tan Securities to trade in Keda shares during the Relevant Period.19 5.3 In this Report, the time an order was entered or executed plays an important role in the review and has been frequently mentioned in the Report.
The format of 00:00:00 hrs is used.

Thus, if a trade was done at 10 seconds after 9.30am in the morning, the time of the trade would be shown as 09:30:10 hrs, and likewise, if an order was placed at 4.00pm in the afternoon, the time the order was entered would be shown as 16:00:00 hrs.
5.4 Also in this Report, "bid" refers to the buying price of the share and "ask" refers to the selling price of the share.

The best "bid" and the best "ask" at any particular point in time represent the "prevailing market" for that share, and would be indicated as "bid/ask" (for example, the prevailing market was $0.085/$0.090 if the best "bid" was at $0.085 and best "ask" at $0.090).
For the Relevant Period, the "bid" and "ask" size for a share priced below a dollar was specified by SGX to be $0.005 or half a cent, as can be seen in the example given.
By observing how the share was traded and the last done price, investors can, generally, get a feel of the prevailing market sentiment of a share.

For example, all things being equal and irrespective of the overall trend, if a share is traded at the "ask" price, it is viewed as more "bullish", whereas if it is done at the "bid" price, it would be viewed as more "bearish".
This is no different from someone looking for an indication of the latest sentiment in the property market.
If a piece of property is transacted at the seller?s price ("ask"), it meant that the buyer is more keen to buy the property and hence is willing to pay what the seller asks for.
On the other hand, if the seller is eager20 to dispose of the property and willing to sell to the buyer at the latter?s price ("bid"), then this would be considered more "bearish".

5.6 Therefore, during the course of a trading day, there will always be this interplay of "bullish" and "bearish" signals which will affect the share market sentiment and hence the trading of the shares.
All things being equal, a "bullish" sentiment would tend to draw in buyers for a particular share whereas a "bearish" one would tend to encourage selling (or buying on a more cautious stance).
5.7 The closing price (end?of?day price) of a share is an important piece of financial information.
It is widely used in charts and technical analysis.
Investment analysts derive ratios and averages from these closing prices and use them extensively in their investment research and for making investment decisions.
Investors make use of price earnings ratios, dividend yield, etc. to assess the worth of a share, the calculations of which are based on closing prices.
Companies use closing prices to set the price of options offered to employees.
5.8 Banks and securities houses use the closing price of a share to compute the adequacy of the value of collaterals in margin accounts offered to clients.
Fund managers use closing prices for their periodic valuation of the funds they manage.
How a fund performs over a month, a quarter or a year is measured by the change in the closing prices of the shares (over the relevant period) in the portfolio.
In turn, this determines the performance of the fund manager and the fees and incentive he collects.110 10.3

Executive Summary 6.1 Keda shares, listed on Catalist, were not actively traded during the Relevant Period.

12422 6.4 In my review of John?s and Lee?s trades, I had looked closely at the price and volume of their orders and trades, the time of their orders and trades, their counter?parties, and the price and volume of other orders and trades immediately before and after them.
The following are my observations and findings in respect of these 58 "Suspicious Trades": a) b)
Suspicious Modus Operandi The sequence and timing of John?s and Lee?s sell and buy orders had given rise to suspicion.
They seemed to have been contrived and carried out in a highly orchestrated manner to ensure that John and Lee ended up trading with one another.
Because the market for Keda shares was illiquid, John and Lee were able to use these transactions to manipulate the market and raise the price of Keda shares.

In addition, the modus operandi they employed was such that they were able to do this without expending too much resource as in many of these trades no shares actually changed hands between John and Lee, and so no money was needed to be paid out by both John and Lee.
On the other hand, where it was necessary to pay for the shares to be delivered, John and Lee kept most of their trading volumes small so as to limit their capital outlay.
Lack of Commercial Basis or Unusually Small Volume 10d) Many of the "Suspicious Trades" done by John and Lee were found to be lacking in commercial logic and purpose.
In many cases, the buying and selling between John and Lee resulted in the passing of a "phantom" block of Keda shares to and fro between John and Lee at the same price.
The net result is that there was no need to deliver or pay for the shares.
For the remaining cases, they were traded in small volumes (as small as 1 or 2 lots), which is unusual for a penny stock like Keda.
Then there were trades that were carried out by John with himself as the counter?party (so there was no change in the beneficial ownership) without any valid reason;
Artificially Raising the Closing Price of Keda Shares

There was a strong inference that 40 of these 58 "Suspicious Trades", were found to have been intentionally carried out as the last trade for the day, resulting in the closing price of Keda shares being artificially raised by between $0.005 and $0.100 or between 1 and 20 "bids; and Genuineness of Trades in Doubt All 58 "Suspicious Trades" were questionable in terms of genuineness, and the manner in which these trades were carried out aroused suspicion.

These trades either did not 11 2324 make commercial sense, or were of unusually small volume (which makes its purpose suspect) and appeared to have been contrived and deliberately carried out in a coordinated manner.
These "Suspicious Trades" were not genuine and the orders, trades, volumes and prices done on these days did not represent the forces of genuine demand and supply of Keda shares on those days.
Keda shares would not have traded the way it did on those days if not for these "Suspicious Trades".

ANALYSIS Background on behalf of their broking house which acts as a principal and not an agent in the transaction with the sole purpose of making an absolute gain from the more volatile movements in a stock during the trading day.

Gains from proprietary trading less transactions costs, which is usually fixed at $$400.00 per stock, are shared equally between the proprietary trader and the stock broking company while losses are only borne lsy the proprietary trader.
Ail positions must be closed within the same trading day, no marred deals or off?
market transactions are permitted with the bulk of the trades being contra? positions.
Collateral or a banker?s guarantee is provided by the proprietary trader to the stock broking company.
The usual practice is for a bankers? guarantee of S$$50,000/? for a trading limit of S$5mn.

Proprietary trading involves cuse ul trading by remisiers and dealers representatives Acceptable trading practices include: a) to purchase a block of shares at the ask price and then enter a sell order one or more bids
higher | b) olace a sell order one or mole bids higher than the current bid/offer and then accumulate as much of the stock but not exceeding the sell order below the sell orice.
Occasionally the sell volume can be adjusted downward or upwards to match the volume of the stock that has been accumulated.
It is usually not possible to influence a stock price unless the trader or those working in concert with him account for at least 70?80% of the trading volume for that particular day.

A common but illegal practice is to create the impression of growing buying or selling interest in a stock that would either entice in new buyers or would encourage existing buyers to sell their stock.
This is usually accomplished by the entry and withdrawal of buy or sell orders as they rex 4 the front of the queue.
The withdrawn order is then re?entered at the same price go that it moves to the back of the queue.
This would create an impression of buy or sell interests which does not actually exists.
We would be looking for the latter two as possible indications of a breach of Section 97 (1) and Section 98 (1) of the Securities Industry Act (SIA) for this case.12 December 2001 ? Amtek Events

In providing the expert opinion, you may consider that all the above transactions were done in the stock account of Philip.
Besides using the said stock account to buy and sell Links shares for clients, the Group also used the stock account as a proprietary account to trade in Links shares.
The industry does not condone any practice that could result in the distortion or manipulation of share prices, traded volume or the market for shares in general.
As the practice of systematic trading at the day end carries a greater probability of such distortions or manipulations, it is not considered good practice within the industry.
Whilst systematic trading at the end of the day may not be good practice it is also not forbidden practice.

For instance, given the time zone of Singapore relative to European and US investors, a brokerage specialising in smaller European or American investors, may display a pattern of undertaking many late and last trades simply because orders from such clients are given late in the afternoon.
Thus systematic trading at the end of the day in itself cannot be said to represent a breach of the Securities Industry Act (Chp 289, 1985 Revised Edition) ("SIA").
For a breach of $97 of the SIA, the following conditions have to be met: 3.3.1 ?
There has been one trade or series of trades; and 3 of 21Private & Confidential I | | | |

The summary table and Annex 1 show that during the Psriod, the pattern of trading by the Group was systematic, intense and significant relative to the available trading days.
In no month did the Group account for less than 50% of day?end closes and in the month of April the Group accounted for every single day?end close.

It is difficult to envisage a situation where such intensity of trading, particularly between 17 March to 2 June 2000 (where the Group accounted for 49 trading day?end closes out of the 53 trading clay?end closes), would not affect investor perception and thus the price and market for Links.
The Group must] have known or should have known that such intensity would have an impact.

There are three major schools of thought with regards market efficiency.
At one extreme, there are those who do not believe markets are efficient.

For such persons, the intensity and systematic pattern of trading described in para 3.4 would, inevitably, distort the market for Links since such an intense and systematic trading pattern must affect the price for Links.
At the other extreme, there are those who believe the market are always efficient unless there are structural impediments or blatant manipulation.
For such persons, para 3.4 would be insufficient evidence.
I belong to the third and largest group which believes that markets are semi?efficient.
This group believes that the level of efficiency, or inefficiency, depends on several factors including investor knowledge of a counter or security.
Singapore is a smallish? market and Links is a smallish counter, thus the level of knowledge by investors is likely to be low.
A priori, this means that even relatively small trades in Links could distort the price of Links creating a false market in the stock.

On this basis it would not be unreasonable for expert opinion to conclude on the basis of para 3.2 alone, that a false and misleading price and market for Links must have been created at several times during the Period and for the Period as a whole.
Given the seriousness of allegations, I am of the opinion that a higher level of confidence needs to be obtained prior to reaching a conclusion.
Accordingly, I have set out four tests.
The tests and their purpose are as follows: 3.6.1 3.6.2 Test 1:

To test that the bias towards a rise, or a fall, in the price of Links, on those days when the Group made a day?end trade, is about the same as, or at least not significantly dissimilar to, the bias towards a rise, or a fall, in the price of Links, on those days when day?end trades were made by persons unassociated with the Group.
This test exams the day?on?day rises and falls to see if the Group?s actions resulted in a directional bias.
A directional bias means the Group?s actions lead to a disproportionate number of day?on?day rises or a disproportionate number of day?on?day falls, in the share price of Links; Test 2:

To test that the differential between the closing price of each day and the highest price reached on each day, on those days when the Group made a day?end trade, is about the same, or at least not significantly dissimilar to, the differential between the closing price of each day and the highest price reached on each day, on those days when the day?end trades were made by persons unassociated with the 5 of 21Private & Confidential ACH Investments Pte Ltd 3.7 Group.
All things being equal, the differentials between the day?end close and the day high should be randomly and normally distributed around the mean/average of the differentials
A deviation would strongly suggest that there are forces or actions acting on the share price of Links which are distorting normal trading patterns; 3.6.3

To test that the pattern of trading of the last 5 trades of Links, on those days when the Group made a day?end trade, is about the same as, or at least not significantly dissimilar to, the pattern of trading of the last 5 trades of Links, on those days when day?end trades were made by persons unassociated with the Group.
This test examines intra?day trading patterns.
day trading pattems are used to examine, in detail, trade action patterns.

This test provides a qualitative feel for the likely importance of the intra?day trading pattern as well as providing insights into "active trading". Test 1.
The day?on?day changes, for the Period, were calculated.
28 February 2000, or the first day of trading, was considered as having no day?on?day price change.
The day?to?day changes were sorted and classified as a rise, a fall or no change.
The results are shown as table 2.

Of the 71 trading days where the Group accounted for the day?end trade, 14 such days saw the closing price lower, 20 such days saw the closing price unchanged and 37 days saw the closing price higher, than the previous day?s closing price.
Given that there were 30 days where the closing price of Links was lower than its previous closing price, this means that the Group accounted for 47% (14 days out of 30 days) only.
All things being equal, the Group should only have accounted for 70% (expected norm), since they account for about 70% of total trading days (71 days out of 101 days).
The results of this test show that there is a significant deviation from norm between those day?end trades that were accounted for by the :Group and those that were accounted for y third parties.

The data strongly suggests that on trading days where the Group accounted for the day? end close, it was far more likely that the closing price would rise instead of fall (the probability of a rise is 2.6 times higher than a fall)}. The data also strongly suggests that on trading days where the Ciroup did not account for the day?end close, it was far more likely that the closing price would fall instead of rise.
The results show that the Group?s actions are highly correlated to the 6 of 21Private & Confidential ACH Investments Pte Ltd direction of the day?on?day closing price changes.
The results suggest that Group?s actions tended to push the share price of Links upwards.

The differential between the closing price of Links and its day high were calculated by way of dividing the day high by the day close and subtracting 1 (high/close ?1).
Thus if the day high is the same as the day close, the differential is 0%.
If the day high was 10% above the day close the differential will be 10%.
The mean/average of these differentials was calculated and this was about 2.5%.
To allow for any errors and to create a reasonable category or interval, we allowed the Mean interval to be 2 to 3%.

If the differentials were randomly and reasonably normally distributed around the Mean, we would expect: (a) to see those days where the Group accounted for the day?end trade be about 70% for all three categories; and (b) for the numbers of days in the Below 2% category to be about equal to the number of days in the Above 3% category.
The data in table 3 clearly shows that the differentials are neither randomly nor normally distributed around the Mean.
The data shows that on the days, on which the Group accounted for the day?end trade, there was a tendency or bias towards a day?end price close similar to or close to the day price high.

During the Period under review, there was a 76% chance (being 69% plus 7%) that if the Group accounted for the day?end trade, the closing price would be at or very near (no more than a 3% deviation) the day high.

One criticism that has been levelled at tests such as those used above is the issue of market consistency.

The liberalization of the Singapore Stock Exchange, which has resulted in the listing of many smaller companies, and weak economic conditions, which have dampened trading volumes on the Exchange, has resulted in low traded volumes in many securities.

The critique of market consistency asks the question of whether or not dealers and traders should be responsible for dealing patterns and actions which may cause distortions in the price, and the market of a security, at this time of low volumes but which may not cause distortions when the market is active.
In other words, can actions that would be considered legal in a buoyant market be illegal in a less buoyant market.
It is fair question which that the securities industry has not resolved.
This is because even if there had been a significant rise in the volume of shares traded in 9 of 21 Sub

I have been asked to provide a written expert opinion ?on whether the 28 trades executed on 5 different days through various brokerage accounts in the shares of the 4 specified counters (?Specified Shares?)? 1.1
With respect to the market for, or the price of ; the Specified Shares; or 1.1.2 Maintained, inflated, depressed, or caused fluctuations in, the market price of the Specified Shares 1.2
In relation to a possible contravention of section 198 of the SFA: Had, or were likely to have had, the effect of raising, lowering, maintaining or stabilizing the price of the Specified Shares.
I have also been asked to include any other issue which I discover in the course of my review that I believe may be relevant to my opinion and/or the case.
There are, basically, two broad categories of share market investors or participants.
They are the short-term traders and the mid- to long-term investors.
The short-term traders look for short-term price changes to make his money.
The duration between his ?buy? and ?sell? trades can be as short as minutes or hours within the same day, or it can extend to the next day, or even a few days later.
Examples of short-term traders are (securities?) house dealers, intra-day traders (day-traders), share speculators, short-term investors, hedge funds, etc.
The mid- to long-term investor, on the other hand, does more research on what shares to buy and relies on the appreciation in share prices over the medium to long term to make his profits.

Hence, such an investor pays more attention on the fundamentals of a company, i.e., its financial strength, profit performance, future profit potential, growth prospects, and its historical and current price levels, before deciding to invest.
His investment time horizon is naturally longer, which can be months or even years.
Some example of mid/long-term investors are unit trusts, insurance companies, pension funds, investment companies, etc.
All investors, however, buy and sell shares with profits in mind.
They will try to maximize profits by buying low and selling high.
Thus, they watch the movements of share prices closely.

In fact, the short-term investors, especially, the day- and contra- traders and speculators not only watch daily share prices closely, they also pay attention to the prevailing market sentiment as reflected by the movements in the share price and volume of trades done.

They are constantly monitoring the price trends of shares during the trade day and will look out, particularly, for ?bullish? and ?bearish? indicators from trades done on the market, especially, the last done price.
A share is traded on SGX based on its daily price quotations as represented by the best ?ask? and ?bid? prices.
If a share is actively traded, the spread between the best ?ask? and best ?bid? is usually 1 ?tick? (or 1 ?bid?).
This is also the smallest amount the share price can change, according to SGX rules.
For example, a share that is trading below $1/-, this ?tick? would be $0.005 (or, in other words, the share price is quoted at half-cent intervals).
Thus, the prevailing ?market? for a share can be shown as, say, $0.12/$0.115, where $0.12 represents the best ?ask? and $0.115 the best ?bid?.
By observing how a share is traded and the last done price, investors can, generally, get a feel of the prevailing market sentiment of a share.
For example, all things being equal, if a share was traded at the ?ask? price, it is viewed as more ?bullish?, whereas if it was done at the ?bid? price, it would be viewed as more ?bearish?.
This is no different from someone looking for an indication of the trend in the property market.
If a piece of property is transacted at the seller?s price (?ask?), it means that the buyer is more keen to buy the property and hence is willing to pay what the seller asks for.
This would likely be interpreted more as a ?bullish? factor.
On the other hand, if the seller is eager to dispose of the property and willing to sell to the buyer at the latter?s price (?bid?), then this would be considered more ?bearish?.
During the course of a trading day, there will always be this interplay of ?bullish? and ?bearish? signals which will affect market sentiment and hence trading of the shares.

Thus, when a trader/investor sees a share done at the ?ask? price, he is likely to interpret it as something more ?bullish? and likewise, if is done at ?bid?, then it would likely be considered more ?bearish?.
These ?bullish? and ?bearish? factors can have an influence on a share trader?s sentiment and, therefore, his decision to buy or sell shares.
All things being equal, a ?bullish? sentiment would tend to draw in buyers whereas a ?bearish? one would tend to encourage selling of a particular share or a more cautious buying stance.
It is useful to bear in mind the explanation above as it would help in the understanding of Ong?s trades and their effect on market and price of the Specified Shares.
All the 4 Specified Shares traded at $0.115 and below and, as such, are generally referred to as ?penny? stocks, which are shares priced substantially below a dollar.
As the capital outlay for one lot of the shares is small, traders would normally trade in larger volumes to have a decent profit.

The trading activities of Ong were reviewed based on the documents provided, in particular, the 5 Listings of ?Orders and Trades? for the shares of IPCO, Goldtron, Anwell and Centillion provided by SGX for the 5 days.
These listings contained information, on a daily basis, on all orders entered into the SGX trading system (including those subsequently deleted or amended) and all the trades done for that day.

The exact time each order was entered, deleted, amended or executed; the last done price and volume; the balance order; the broker; the counter-parties, etc., and the best ?ask?/?bid? at that point in time; would all be shown chronologically, from the time the trading system opened till the close of trading each day.
It should be pointed out that these listings actually provide more information than what the investing public are able to see on the trading screens.
This Review, however, is based on these listings where the chronology of events could be re-constructed and all of Ong?s orders and trades examined in detail.

Hence all of Ong?s actions, including the time at which Ong entered his orders and the time at which the trades were done can be obtained from these listings and the chronology of events, would be captured in these listings and can be reviewed in detail.
In my Report, the format of ?hour:minute:second? has been used to refer to the ?time? an order was entered or when a trade was done.

For example, if an order was entered at 45 seconds after 9.13am in the morning, the time would be shown as ?09:13:45?, and likewise, if the trade was done at 4pm in the afternoon, it would be shown as ?16:00:00?.
It was possible, therefore, based on these 5 listings of ?Orders and Trades? provided by SGX to re-construct the manner in which Ong traded in the Specified Shares during those 5 days.
For the purpose of his Report, I have been instructed to assume that all the 28 trades were carried out by Ong.
Based on the documents provided, all the 28 trades were, indeed, carried out through Ong?s account with different brokerages and as well as electronically through the Internet.

to create a ?bullish? sentiment and draw in investors to buy at the ?ask? price of these shares.

112A. I would like to elaborate, however, on the reasons why I had come to the opinions stated below, even though the 28 trades done were for very small lots (except for one trade for 154 lots).
It should be pointed out that often times, during trading, the investing public tend to focus mainly on price movements and could easily miss or overlook the volume factor.
They are likely to associate repeated price movements up and down as a sign of active trading, unless the share is known to be thinly traded and inactive to begin with.
In this case, the overall volume traded for these Specified Shares for those 5 days ranged from about 4,000 to 15,000 lots, which is unlikely to be considered inactive.
This view is, in fact, borned out by what Ong did.
As an experienced trader, he must have concluded that he needed only to trade such small lots (but carefully timed) to create the appearance he wanted the investing public to observe.
He was confident that these would be enough to affect their trading sentiment.
By doing so, he had hoped to achieve his goal of drawing in buyers at the higher ?ask? price, a price at which he was keenly awaiting to sell as part of his main strategy.

Ong must have found that trading such small amounts each time was effective enough to serve his purpose as he had continued to operate in the same manner with the shares of Goldtron, Anwell and Centillion, after IPCO.

The securities market is an important component of Singapore?s finance industry.
It provides companies with a convenient and useful place to raise capital and likewise the public an opportunity to invest in these companies.
This is where the seekers of capital and the suppliers meet.
The securities market in Singapore is operated by the SGX, which also acts as its self? regulatory body.
The SGX issues rules and regulations for all participants and expects them to be complied with.
The government agency that oversees this is3.3. 3.4. 3.5.
In addition, all aspects of securities trading come under the Securities and Futures Act, Chapter 289 (SFA).
The general public can and do invest in shares listed on SGX.
The SGX has the primary responsibility to regulate and ensure that a fair and orderly market exists at all times for the trading of all securities listed on it.
SGX encourages transparency and requires timely disclosure of price?sensitive information and constantly guards against non?compliance, including insider? trading and market manipulation.
The laws and the strict SGX rules and regulations are there to protect the integrity of the stock market and the interests of all participants.
Any doubt here will have serious implications on SGX?s and the securities market?s credibility and future.
Share investors can be broadly divided into 2 categories: one, those who trade for short?term gains and two, those who buy and hold shares for the mid/long?term.
In this Report, the general investing public will be referred to simply as "investors".
Share "traders" will be used only for those who are known to trade mainly for the short term.
Whoever they are, however, there is but one common objective and, that is, to profit from the trades/investment through a favourable movement in the share price.
While the goal for profits is the same, they do behave differently when it comes to trading shares.
The short?term trader looks for short?term price movements to make his money.
The duration between his ?buy? and ?sell? trades can be as short as within the same day, the next day, a few days or some weeks.
He is not too concerned with the company?s fundamentals as long as he is convinced of a quick potential price rise.
However, he considers a counter?s volatility and liquidity as important factors as these will maximise his profit opportunities and enable him to enter and exit the market quickly.3.8.
The mid/long?term investor, on the other hand, does more research on what counters to buy and hence pays more attention on the fundamentals of a company, ie.
He looks more for the counter?s price performance/appreciation over time, which can be months or even years later.
When a decision is made to buy a particular counter he will make his purchase according to market conditions.
If his purchase quantity is significant, he will buy rationally and will usually accumulate his shares over a reasonable period of time, so as not to push up the share price in the process.
His aim is to get in at the best possible price for the quantity he wants to invest.
In addition to price, liquidity of the counter is also important to him.
For trades that are bigger, he needs sufficient liquidity to buy his quantity at a reasonable price and to exit easily when he sells.
A counter is considered liquid when a sizable volume of that share can be traded each time without significantly affecting the price.
One common characteristic of a liquid counter is a narrow spread of usually one ?tick? or ?bid {explained at Para 3.12 below) between the ?ask? and ?bid? prices.
Generally, the ?blue chips? and shares of bigger companies are more liquid as they attract a larger group of investors and are traded more often and in bigger volumes each day.
This is not the case for many of the smaller companies whose shares are thinly traded and, more often than not, have only a small group of following investors.
Thus an illiquid or thinly traded counter is usually difficult to buy in, for sizeable quantity, and hard to get out without the price being adversely affected.
At times, the market spread between the ?ask? and ?bid? prices of an illiquid share can be significant (i.e. several ?bids away).
A counter is traded on SGX based on its daily market price quotations as represented by the best ?ask? and ?bid? prices (also commonly referred to as the ?market).

If a counter is actively traded (liquid), the ?market? for this counter will always have a narrow spread (?market spread?) of usually 1 ?bid ? i.e. the best ?ask and ?bid> prices will differ only by 1 ?bid?, which is the minimum amount the share3.13.
According to SGX rules applicable during the Relevant Period, for a counter trading above $1/?, this 1 ?bid? is $0.01 and for those trading below $1/?, it is $0.005.

Thus, the market for a share can be shown as, say, $1.12/$1.11(ask/bid) or $0.85/$0.845, if it is below $1/?. If, on the other hand, the market spread of a particular counter is usually more than a few ?bids?, e.g. $0.82/$0.79, then it is likely that this counter is illiquid.
By observing how a counter is traded and the last done price, investors can, generally, get a feel of the prevailing market sentiment of a share.

For example, all things being equal, and irrespective of the overall trend, if a share is traded at the ?ask? price, it is a ?bullish? signal, whereas if it is done at the ?bid> price, it is considered ?bearish.
This is no different from someone looking for an indication of, say, the latest sentiment in the property market.
If a piece of property is transacted at the seller?s price (?ask?), it means that the buyer is more keen to buy the property and pay what the seller asks for.
On the other hand, if the seller is eager to dispose of the property and willing to sell to the buyer at the latter?s price (*?bid?), then this is a ?bearish? signal.
In the course of a trading day, there will always be this interplay of ?bullish? and ?bearish? signals which will affect the prevailing market sentiment and the trading behaviour of investors.
A ?bullish sentiment would tend to attract buyers into the market or discourage selling, whereas a ?bearish? one would tend to force out sellers or discourage buying. Investor Protection
Ensuring a fair and orderly market and investor protection are some of the top priorities of SGX.

Apart from making sure that listed companies comply with the laws, rules and regulations applicable to listed companies, SGX has, over the years, implemented various measures to protect the interests of the investing public.
In the past, the market opens at 0900 hrs and closes at 1700 hrs sharp.
In this system, the first opening trade and the last closing trade determined the opening 73.19. 3.20. and closing prices, respectively, regardless of the quantity traded.
These prices, therefore, may or may not be representative of the actual demand and supply at opening and closing.

The system was changed to one where, before the market opens each day, orders to sell (?ask?) and buy (?bid?) are keyed in on to a queue during the pre?opening routine which will then be matched by an algorithm to determine the opening price at 0900 hrs, a process very similar to the bidding of the Certificate of Entitlement.
The ?matched? price becomes the opening price for that share.
Similarly, after 5 pm each day, all ?ask? and ?buy? orders are placed on a queue during the pre?close routine and matched.
The price matched at 1705 hrs will be the closing price.
This change was believed to have been introduced to ensure that the opening and closing prices were more representative of the actual supply and demand of the shares at those times.
A below is extracted from SGX?s website showing one of the many examples on how the matched price during the pre?close routine is computed.
Example of how prices are matched on SGX during pre?close routine3.21.

In this example, the sell pressure changes to buy pressure at $10.50 and $10.60 and since the same number of trades (18 lots) can be executed at both these prices, the final computed price will be the price that is closer to the last traded price.
If, say, the last traded price was $10.40, then the computed price will be $10.50.
The closing price of a counter, in particular, is a key piece of financial information.
It is widely used in charts and technical analysis.
Share analysts derive ratios and averages from these closing prices and use them extensively in their investment research.
Fund managers typically use the closing prices at the end of a month, the end of a quarter and the end of a year for periodic valuation of the funds they manage.
How a fund performs over a month, a quarter or a year, thus, depends on the closing prices of the shares in the portfolio.
In turn, this determines the performance of the fund manager and the fees and incentives he collects.
A higher closing price will benefit the fund manager.

The trading activities of MAOF, Mart and Nuni were reviewed based on the documents provided, in particular, the 2 listings of the "Details of Orders and Trades in Sincere Shares" and "Details of Orders and Trades in RSH Shares" provided by SGX.
These listings contained information, on a daily basis, of all orders entered into the SGX trading system, including those subsequently deleted or amended, and all the trades done for that day.

The information shown included, chronologically, the exact time the orders were entered, deleted, amended or executed; the price and volume done; the balance order; the broker; the counter? parties, etc., and the best ?ask"?/ bid? (i.e. the ?prevailing market?) at that point in time.
In this Report, the time an order was entered or executed is important and is frequently mentioned in the Report.

For example, if a trade was done at 45 seconds after 9.13am in the morning, the time would be shown as 09:13:45 hrs, and likewise, if the trade was done at 4.00 pm in the afternoon, it would be shown as 16:00:00 hrs.
It was possible, therefore, based on these listings to re?construct how Nuni used MAOF, Mart and his own personal account to trade in Sincere and RSH shares during the Relevant Period.
