Possible Motive of Nuni 8.40 8.41 Firmer share prices at month
Generally, investors are more ?bullish about the market around these times.
These dates coincide with the end of the financial reporting periods (quarterly, half?yearly or yearly) of SGX?listed companies.

Many believed that some ?window?dressing? will take place on these dates as fund managers buy shares with the hope of lifting prices to boost the valuation of their investment portfolios and, therefore, enhance their performance.
But ?window dressing? trades are hard to carry out and even harder to detect if the trades are conducted in very liquid counters.
Nevertheless, if enough investors believe that 198.42 8.43 8.44 8.45 this phenomenon is true and accordingly, enter the market, the overall effect can result in an increase in share prices.
The manner in which Nuni traded did not make commercial sense for thinly?traded counters like Sincere and RSH.

No prudent investor, fund manager or investment holding company would leave the bulk of his purchases till the end of the day or month and then rush to complete the orders by buying at progressively higher ?ask prices when the trading was about to close.

Normally, one would accumulate shares throughout the day and be mindful not to push up the share price (and one?s cost) if one is buying a sizable amount, especially, when the counters are thinly traded like that of Sincere or RSH.
In the case of Nuni, he did the exact opposite and deliberately traded to cause the rise in the closing price of Sincere and RSH.

As a fund manager, Nuni knew or ought to know that the closing price of a share is a key piece of financial information used by investors, chartists, investment analysts, fund managers and even corporations to track the performance of companies.
Closing prices of shares are used to derive ratios, averages and other financial indicators crucial for making investment decisions.
Fund managers use closing prices of shares at the end of a month, a quarter and a year, for valuation purposes.
The performance of a fund and the fund manager are dependent on the increment in value of the shares portfolio over an agreed time frame.
A higher closing price would increase the valuation of a fund and hence its performance.
This will in turn benefit the fund manager, whose fees and bonuses (if any) are tied to the performance of the fund.

As Nuni is a fund manager, it is possible that he had conducted the trades in Sincere and RSH with the intention of raising the counters? share prices so as to benefit from the higher valuations in the two counters.

~ Closing Price Chart 1; Daily Price and Volume of Sincere Shares before and after the Group?s Trades The following observations and findings were noted in respect of Nuni?s trades in Sincere shares.
It was noted that Nuni appeared to be trading with the intention to artificially raise the closing price of Sincere shares during seven distinct periods as elaborated below.
Nuni also conducted cross (washed?) trades on 12 instances during the seven periods to further the objective of raising the closing price of Sincere shares.
There were seven periods during which Nuni traded to artificially raise the closing price of Sincere shares.
These seven periods were : a _ 22?29 December 2006, 221.9 1.10 1.11

The December 2006 stretch comprised of 5 trading days ending with the month?end on 29 December 2006 (which was also a year?end) and the January period comprised of two trading days ending with the month?end on 31 January 2007.
The rest of the remaining five periods were month?ends themselves.

During all these seven periods, Nuni had traded actively in Sincere shares (using the accounts of MAOF and Mart and at times using his own personal account) near the end of the trading day and/or during the pre?close routine.

By progressively buying Sincere shares at the late hour and at prices which were 1 or more ?bids? higher than the last done price, Nuni?s trades had the effect of lifting the closing price of Sincere shares.
Table D below shows a summary of the trades done by the Group during these seven periods (over a total of twelve days).
It can be seen that the total volume traded by the Group as a percentage of the day?s total volume traded ranged from 39% to a high of 99%.
Table D also shows the last trade of the day by the Group (which set the closing price) and the increase in the closing price over the previous trading day?s, ranged between $0.020 and $0.590.
In addition, Table D further illustrates the last price done in the market by ?Others (assuming this would be the closing price if the Group?s trades were not conducted).

Other than the following three days (i.e. 27 December 2007, 31 January 2007 and 31 August 2007), the Group?s trades had caused the closing price of Sincere shares to increase by between $0.010 to $0.620.

Price and Volume of Sincere Shares on 31 August 2007 Conclusion and Opinion 1.88 The evidence clearly showed that Nuni had, using his personal account and those of MAOF and Mart, deliberately traded to raise the closing price of Sincere shares during these seven periods.
1.89 His modus operandi was to trade only small lots at the beginning of a month right up to a few days prior to the month?end.
After this, and especially at the month?end, he then traded in larger volume.
As Sincere shares were thinly traded, Nuni was able to raise the closing price with such purchases.
During all the 12 days in these seven periods, the Group?s trades accounted for much of the buying and the day?s total trading volume.

Label: Event
Feature: Shares traded by suspects vs total outstanding shares
Sentence: The Group?s total trades (purchases) on each day ranged from 39% to as high as 99% of the day?s total trading volume.
Nuni also left the bulk of his purchases not only to the end of the month but also close to the end of the trading day and/or during the pre?close routine.
1.96 Appendix A Group?s purchases on the seven month?ends were carried out in the last half?hour of trading before 17:00:00 hrs and/or during the pre?close routine.
When Nuni bought Sincere shares during these seven periods, it was done not in the way a prudent investor would do.
The purchases were done often in quick succession and late in the day, with each subsequent purchase made at a higher price.
These purchases were often done at prices which were several ?bids? higher than the last done price.
During these seven periods, Nuni also resorted to ?washed? trades to raise the price of Sincere shares.
Nuni would typically use one of the accounts to enter a sale order at prices which were several bids higher than the prevailing traded price.
Thereafter, Nuni will make use of the remaining accounts to purchase Sincere shares up to the price which he had earlier set for his sale order, resulting in "washed" trades between the accounts.
In doing so, Nuni was able to register a higher transacted price for Sincere shares.
On all of the 12 days in these seven periods, the Group also did the last trade of the day and accordingly, set the closing price.
These last trades were either done during the pre?close routine (on 9 of the 12 days) or shortly before trading ended (on 3 of the 12 days).

Based on the evidence, it is my opinion that Nuni and his Group?s actions were deliberate and intended to artificially raise the closing price of Sincere shares on these seven periods.
Their trades had created a false or misleading appearance with respect to the price of Sincere shares.

The investigation relates to allegations of market rigging offences under Section 97 of the Securities Industry Act, Cap 289 1985 Revised Edition ("SIA") and Section 197 of the Securities and Futures Act, Cap 289 ("SFA") involving the shares of Novena Holdings Ltd ("Novena") for the period between 3 June 2002 and 9 September 2003.
The suspect is one Lawrence Yip Choy ("Yip").
Yip traded in various securitites trading accounts in the names of: (1) Andy Tay Teck Boon ("Tay") (2)
Brief Background of the Case Novena is a company whose shares are listed on the Singapore Exchange Dealing & Automated Quotation System (°SESDAQ").
The company is in the business of manufacturing and retailing of household furniture and furnishings.
Between 3 June 2002 and 9 September 2003, Novena was traded on 165 days.

Label: Event
Feature: Number of days suspects' trades accounted for more than 50% of market volume
Sentence: The total market volume traded on this counter was 37,293,000 shares.

Label: Event
Feature: Shares traded by suspects vs total outstanding shares
Sentence: Yip traded in Novena using a total of 9 accounts in the names of 4 persons, narnely Tay, Teo, Chan and Chow.

Label: Event
Feature: Number of days a specific event happened vs number of days suspects traded over the review period
Sentence: He traded on 157 out of the 165 trading days during the period between 3 June 2002 and 9 September 2003.Terms of Reference Re:

Lawrence Yip Choy To provide an expert opinion in relation to possible offences by Lawrence Yip Choy ("Yip") under Section 97(1) of the Securities Industry Act (Cap 289, 1985 Revised Edition) and/or Section 197(1) of the Securities and Futures Act (Cap 289) involving his trades in the shares of Novena Holdings Ltd ("Novena") for the period between 3 June 2002 and 9 September 2003.

Label: Event
Feature: Shares traded by suspects vs total outstanding shares
Sentence: Yip used the securities trading accounts in the names of the following 4 persons to execute substantial transactions in Novena: (1) Andy Tay Teck Boon (2)

To provide an opinion on whether any of the transactions, or any combination of the transactions executed in the accounts of the 4 persons, as listed in Appendix XX, create or show an attempt to create a false or misleading appearance of active trading or cause a false or misleading appearance of the market for and/or the price of Novena for the period between 3 June 2002 and 9 September 2003.
To provide details of how this had happened and the extent to which this had happened.

On the assumption that Yip controlled the trading of the 9 accounts belonging to the above mentioned 4 persons, ie that the trades, though transacted through various accounts was effectively the work of one person:
In my opinion, the collection of data suggests that the trades, taken together, did create a false or misleading appearance of active trading in Novena over the prescribed time period.

Basis Several factors for deciding whether a false or misleading appearance of active trading were considered: The presence of matched trades; The significant volume and value of these matched trades; The frequency of these matched trades: The lengthy duration through which a combination of these factors was olbserved.
The Presence of Matched Trades: £ @
For every stock transaction there is a purchase and a sale.
A matched trade here rafers to a situation where the purchase and the sale of a counter in a transaction are made by the same controlling entity.
The effect of such an action is that market volume is created, but with no effective change in control.
The additional volume arising from matched trades is thus "artificial", giving an impression that there is greater demand/supply of the stock than is actually the case.
Thus it contributes towards creating a false and misleading appearance of active trading.
Over the period 3 June 2002 to 9 September 2003, the presence of matched trades between the accounts of Tay Teck Boon, Teo Luck Hong, Chan Kin Kay and Chow Hoong Wei, was noted on 112 days.
How do we assess the significance of matched trades?

In considering whether a false or misleading appearance of active trading was created, the significance of matched trades must be considered in relation to the transactional liquidity of the stock itself, in this case, Novena.
Transactional liquidity is expressed in terms of dollar?value (in short, value), which is the volume (number of shares) multiplied by price of a transaction.
The average value of the Suspect?s matched trades per day, on those days in which matched trades were observed, was $39,022.

The average purchase size of Novena per market participant (excluding the matched trades) over the review period was approximately $20,272 and the average sales size of Novena was approximately $11,262.

This was computed by taking the $ value of the transactions done on Novena (excluding those of the Suspect?s matched trades) divided by the number of market participants involved in those transactions on a particular day, and averaging it out over the review period.
? Basically, these two figures represents or gives us an idea of the average size of transaction per market participant over that period.
The significance of the $?value of matched trades done by the Suspect must be considered in relation to the transactional liquidity of Novena.

if, for example, a value of $39,022 was compared against the transactional liquidity of the stock DBS Group Holdings, which during the same period saw an average daily value of $37.8 million worth of stock traded, it must be concluded that the value of the matched trades is not significant in relation to the overall volume of DBS.
In this particular case, however, we see that the value of matched trades is significant when compared to the average purchase and sales value per market participant in Novena during that period .

The average value of matched trades, at $39,022, is not only significant in terms of size, but also exceeds the average purchase and sales size per market participant in Novena of $20,272 and $11,262 respectively.
The reasoning behind the comparison of these figures is as follows:

The average purchase and sales volume per market participant gives us an idea of the quantity of Novena shares in $?value that an "average" investor in Novena during that period would look to buy or sell.

This "average" investor would look at the market volume of Novena to assess if there would be any liquidity constraints (that is, constraints pertaining to difficulty in fulfilling an order due to insufficient transactional liquidity) either current or potential (as in difficulty with transactional liquidity when it comes to selling the shares).

He/she would be lulled into a false notion that Novena shares trade more actively than in reality (the inflated volume caused by the presence and relatively large volume of matched trades) and it is reasonable to assume that the he/she reached this conclusion because of the relatively large size of the matched trades, in relation to the size of the average purchase or sale.

Further observations to support the significance of the Suspect?s matched trades: Over the period 3 June 2002 to 9 September 2003,There were 35 days and 13§ days respectively in which the value of matched trades exceeded the laverage purchase size and sales size per market participant in Novena.
There were 42 days in which the Suspect?s matched trades accounted for 130% of the market volume in Novena.
There were at least 96 days in which the Suspect?s matched trades accounted for more than 50% of the market volume in Novena. 3.
The frequency with which these matched trades was detected also supports the case for the creation of a false or misleading appearance of active trading.
This situation was certainly not a case of sporadic matching of trades.
Over the period 3 June 2002 to 9 September 2003, there were 322 market days, of whish the number of days in which there was transacted volume in Novena was 155 days.

Label: Event
Feature: Number of days a specific event happened vs number of days suspects traded over the review period
Sentence: Matched trades, involving the accounts of Tay, Teo, Chan and Chow was observed in 112 days out of these 165 days ? a frequency ratio of 68%.
The: Lenthy Duration through which a Combination of these Factors was Observed.
The presence, frequency and significant size of the Suspect?s matched trades provides a basis for an opinion a the creation of an appearance of active trading.
The prevalence of this observation over a prolonged period further reinforces the creation of an appearance of active trading.
Again, this was no sporadic or isolated occurrence of matched trades.

The pattern shows not only the presence of matched trades, but matched trades on a significant and large scale (within the context of Novena?s normal trading volume during that period), occuring frequently and over a prolonged period.
The pattern of matched trades executed by the Suspect was observed between 3 June 2002 through till 9 September 2003 ? a period of 15 months.
Do the trades reflect an intention to rollover trades, ie extend the setilement period?|I in such a scenario, the Suspect intends to "own" a certain quantity of Novena shares.
He does not have the capital to fund the purchase, hence he embarks on this strategy of rolling over the trade.
He does this by purchasing X number of Novena shares in the account of Person A.
When the time comes to settle the purchase transaction (within T+7 days), the Suspect sells the holdings under Person A to another account he controls under
Person B. This way, the Suspect retains economic ownership of X quantity of Novena shares.
There is no capital outlay involved, and he only bears the 2?way transaction costs, as well as the net proceeds (ie sales less purchase).
He repeats this sequence when the next settlement period is due.
This goes on, until the original rationale for owning the Novena shares in the first instance is no longer valid or has met its objective.
in most cases, the underlying objective or rationale for wanting to own the shares in the first instance is a profit?related motive.
The action of closing out a long position within the settlement period (otherwise known as contra?trading) is to avoid the associated capital outlay of the said purchase.
The intention of the initial purchase, however, cannot be determined from this action.
My opinion is that the pattern of the Suspect?s trading is not inconsistent with that of rolling over trades to extend the settlement period.
My conclusion is based on the observation that the pattern of trades are mostly contained within a T+7 days time frame, that is, the shares purchased are sold within T+7 days.
The action of rolling over trades serves the intention of delaying settlement and avoiding the capital outlay associated with the purchases of the shares.
However, It should be noted that in no way is this incompatible with an intention to create an appearance of active trading.
If it is the intention of the Suspect merely to extend the settlement period, then the pattern of matched trades would have to be consistent with such an intention.
There would be 2 factors in this consistency: 1.
The trades would have been fairly lumpy, ie mostly occuring only at 7 day intervals, and; 2.
? The quantum would also be fairly consistent in each 7?day interval.
However, it is observed that the pattern of the Suspect?s matched trades does not portray this:
There were numerous occasions where the matched trades of the Suspect ran for 3 consecutive days or more.
The most notable instance was the period 12 August 2002 to 11 September 2002
when the Suspect?s matched trades occurred on 23 consecutive market days.

This pattern of a prolonged sequence of matched trades on consecutive market days intuitively runs counter to a strategy or intention of rolling over trades, where one would expect to see matched trades interspersed at regular (T+7) day intervals.
The disparity in the daily volume of matched trades is also inconsistent with an intention to merely extend the settlement period.
The volume of daily matched trades ranges from a modest 2,000 shares to a huge 554,000 shares.
See attach@d chart for the volume dispersion of the Suspect?s daily matched trades.

Label: Reason
Sentence: With regards to SIA 97 (4): 1 arn of the opinion that the "rolling over of trades" [defined as a sequence of repetitive trades involving acquiring and closing of a long position within a settlement period such that there is no cash outlay for the capital value of the transaction, only the net proceeds plus transactions cost is borne], does not rule out the purpose of creating a false or misleading appearance of active trading.

Label: Reason
Sentence: The act of rolling over trades itself does not preclude such a purpose or intention.
This can be highlighted by a simple analogy or example.
Assuming a person has the intention to create a false or misleading appearance of active trading on Counter ABC.

He could do this via several ways ? one of them would be to buy and sell shares using proxies, and so as to minimise his cash outlay for those trades, he would close out the positions within the settlement period so that he incur only the transaction costs and the net gain/loss.
This method would reduce his financial requirements arising from his trades, but the act does not in any way preclude an intention of creating an dppearance of active trading.
Docs the pattern of transactions of the Suspect suggest an underlying strategy to trade in Novena shares for profit, while avoiding the capital outlay associated with the purchases?
An examination of the economics of the Suspect?s transactions suggest this is not the case.

Choice of Stock to execute strategy: Such a strategy would normally have been employed in a more liquid stock, herice avoiding the need to complicate issues by involving matched trades to such a degree as observed in this case.

Over the review period, the Suspect?s matched trades amounted to 12.788m shares, compared to 4.094m shares (average of buy and sell quantities for cornparison purpose) worth of trades between the Suspect and bona?fide third parties.

It seems again to me rather unlikely that a rational trader would continue such a trading strategy in the face of such profitless evidence.

Thus, taking into consideration the above factors, | find it very unlikely that the Suspect was engaging in a strategy to trade for profit, while rolling over the trades to avoid the capital outlay associated with such purchases. CONCLUSION

Whether the transaction involving 815,000 OCBC Bank foreign shares ("The Shares") on 13" August 1999 created or were likely to create a false or misleading appearance of active trading in The Shares in contravention of Section 97(1) read with Section 97(3)(a) of the Securities Industry Act.

As noted previously, the transaction involving The Shares are unusual and suspect since there are very few instances in which an investor would use two brokers and in such a contrived manner to cross stock.
However, suspicious transactions in themselves may not lead to a "false or misleading appearance of active trading".
1.2.1 I note that in various judgments in the US, UK and Australia, the term false was be viewed slightly differently.

Given that S97 closely reflects the wording of $124 of the Securities Industry Act of NSW, Australia, it has long been my preference to use the definition of ?false in the manner used in the Australian Commonwealth High Court case of North v Marra Developments Ltd (1981)

In North Mason, J stated that "It is not altogether easy to translate the generality of this language [S124] into a specific prohibition against injurious activity, whilst at the same time leaving people free to engage in legitimate commercial activity which will have an effect on the market and the price of securities.

Purchases or sales are often made for indirect or collateral motives, in circumstances where the transactions will, to the knowledge of the participants, have an effect on the market 1 of 6Private & Confidential ACH Investments Pte Ltd 1.2.2 1.2.3 for, or the price of, shares.
Plainly enough it is not the object of the section to outlaw all such transactions.".
With this, Mason, J makes it clear that false does not mean ?artificial but rather ?not true?.
in this respect the intention or mens rea behind the transaction is important.
Specifically why did Goh Seng Heng ("Goh") transfer The Shares in the way he did?
If the real reason was to increase, decrease or stabilize the price or trading volumes of OCBC (F), then given my understanding of Mason J?s words, the transaction was ?not real? and thus false.

If, however, it was simply because an artificial transaction was the easiest arrangement to achieve Goh?s goal and if the transaction did not intentionally or unintentionally become injurious to the wider investment public, then I will conclude that the transaction is ?not false? in the context of S97.

I draw your attention to the recent Australian case involving Normura International where it was held that the use to a series of artificial transactions within the context of an arbitrage was not false.
But the use of sell orders to specifically depress prices in order to get a higher options value did create a false price in the shares being sold.
In para 3.1 to 3.4 below, whilst I have some doubts as to whether the reasons given by Goh were the complete reasons, given the actions taken they constitute reasonable reasons.
| realize that expert witnesses should not make statements with regards the law but give their opinion about a particular set of facts or developments.
However, given the definition of false? being used, I have presumed to use the principle that I must accept Goh?s reasons in the absence of proof of any other alternative intent.
In para 1.3, I concluded that the wider investment public was unlikely to have acted on or be prejudiced by the increased volume in OCBC (F) shares caused by Goh?s transaction.
1.3 and 3.1 to 3.4, it is my opinion the transactions in The Shares, did not create or was unlikely to have created a false appearance of active trading.
Below is the chart of the trading volumes of OCBC (F) for the month of August 1999.
The red line is the total volume on the 13" of August 1999 (i.e. including The Shares) whilst the blue line excludes trade in The Shares.

Note that other trades may have taken place if the trade in The Shares did not take place ? in other words, the blue line cannot be taken as the volume OCBC (F) may have recorded if Goh did not execute his trade.
did not create or was unlikely to have created a misleading appearance of active trading.).
Whilst the trades were done at the upper range of prices traded for on the 13" of August, and whilst the volume recorded may have been lower, | am relatively certain
that few if any investors would have allowed this series of intraday transactions to affect their decision making.
Thank you for attaching Endresz v Whitehouse for my attention.
| have found the case useful in the past.
I feel the main and fundamental difference between this case and Goh?s transactions are: a
There was clear evidence that Endresz?s needed the price of Emu Hill Gold Mines to rise and stay high in order to get margin financing.

From this the court concluded that this and not his stated motive was the primary motive in executing the series of trades in Emu; Endresz would and did benefit from the price rise of Emu Hill Gold Mines; The price and volume of shares traded rose very significantly due to Endresz?s actions; and It was an expert opinion?s view that the substantial rise in the resultant price and volume of Emu shares could and would have affect investor behaviour with respect to Emu shares.

With respect to Goh?s trade in The Shares: 3 of 6Private & Confidential ACH Investments Pte Ltd e) ? There is no compelling evidence that Goh needed the price of OCBC (F) to remain high or that this was his primary objective.
Whilst there were better ways of achieving his stated objectives (para 3a to 3d), there is a level of consistency and believability between what he did and the reasons given; f) ?
Goh would have benefited from a sustained rise in OCBC (F) stock but
It is my opinion that the impact of the trade done would not have affected investor behaviour.

To provide a written expert opinion on the issues set out below in relation to the instructions given to purchase / orders or transactions in the shares of United Envirotech Limited (?UET?) executed in brokerage account no. 05-1072044 maintained by Pheim Asset Management Sdn Bhd with UOB Kay Hian Pte Ltd during the period between 29 and 31 December 2004, as shown in Annex E (in soft copy):

Whether the instructions given to purchase / orders or transactions in UET shares created a false or misleading appearance of the price of the UET shares; Where a broker is asked to trade with ?careful discretion?, what is generally understood by ?careful discretion?; If the broker in the present case had on the respective days been instructed by the client to carry out the transactions in UET shares with ?careful discretion?, whether the broker exceeded the authority granted to him by purchasing the UET shares in the manner that he did;

Given the market conditions at the material time, what was the degree of impact on the transactions in the UET shares on the price, volume and market of UET shares; and What was the impact and implication of the rise in UET?s share price on the portfolio valuations of the accounts managed by Pheim Asset Management (Asia)
Please indicate any assumptions or qualifications which may apply to your opinion on the above issues and provide an explanation and/or basis for them.
Please also explain any terms of art used in your written expert opinion.
This expert opinion has been prepared in the knowledge that it may be used in a court of law.

Not withstanding the fact that this expert opinion was requested by the MAS, I confirm that this expert opinion is independent in the sense that the opinions it sets forth have not been influenced by the MAS and has been prepared to assist the Court rather than to support the case before me.
I further confirm that I understand my duties as an expert witness to the Court and that I have complied with such duties.
The facts provided to myself are those that have been labeled Annex E to Annex L in the MAS briefing file and detailed in Appendix 2 of this Report.
I have also reviewed the website of Pheim (www.pheim.com.sg) and the website of UET (www.unitedenvirotech.com).
I have also Googled articles on UET around and during the Relevant Period for background information.
These facts are the whole of the facts that were provided and used by myself in reaching the conclusion outlined in this Expert Opinion Report.
All my expert opinions rely on one significant assumption - that the trading efficiency of the Singapore Stock Market is best described by the ?semi-strong form? market efficiency theory.
This market theory states that equity markets are generally efficient but are not always or wholly efficient.

There are rival theories and they include: a ?strong form? theory that postulates that stock markets are wholly efficient; and a ?weak form? theory that postulates that stock markets are wholly inefficient.
In a wholly efficient market (?strong form?) all information is known and thus no action undertaken by any person can distort or manipulate the market.
In a wholly inefficient market (?weak form?) very little information is available to, or known by, investors.
Thus all actions distort the market significantly.
It is my experience that most of my fellow professionals in the finance industry adhere to the semi-strong form market efficiency assumption.

Shall mean or refer to MBR Membrane BioReach, a proprietary technology used by UET in its water treatment process Pheim (Malaysia) Pheim Asset Management Sdn Bhd Pheim (Singapore) Pheim Asset Management Pte Ltd Relevant Period 29 to 31 December 2004, inclusive Report Expert Opinion Report Share or Shares

Pheim is a fund management company.
According to its website, there are two Pheim fund management companies, one incorporated in Singapore and another incorporated in Malaysia.
According to the website, these two Pheim funds share certain common shareholders.
According to the website, there are no cross holdings between the Pheim funds.
I have been instructed to consider Pheim (Malaysia), meaning Pheim Asset Management Sdn Bhd.
Whether the instructions given to purchase / orders or transactions in UET shares created a false or misleading appearance of the price of the UET shares?
I believe that the Securities Laws of Singapore were propagated to protect the integrity of the Republic?s capital markets.
I do not believe they were propagated to prohibit real and legitimate demand even if this demand is significant and has a significant impact on the volume, price and market of a security.

Thus for me to conclude that ?the instructions given to purchase / orders or transactions in UET shares created a false or misleading appearance of the price of the UET shares?, I believe I need to firstly conclude that: Pheim (Malaysia)?s orders were not genuine in the sense that a genuine buyer would not have bought the Shares at the time they were bought and/or in the manner in which they were bought and/or at the price they were bought.

For example: a genuine buyer of a significant amount of shares, in a thinly traded security, would normally spread their purchases over the course of a day so as to minimize the upward impact on the purchase price of the shares thereby ensuring that the shares are acquired at the lowest possible price.

For example: a genuine buyer of a significant amount of shares, in a thinly traded security, would normally take any opportunity to acquire a large block of shares from another shareholder, either ?off? or ?on? the market, rather than buying from the market as it significantly reduces the risk of the buyer not getting enough shares or paying more for the shares desired.
For example: a genuine buyer of a significant amount of shares in a thinly traded security would normally execute a trading pattern designed to minimize share price volatility.

A genuine buyer would want to minimize price volatility since such volatility could impact the risk rating of the fund and since increased volatility could increase the cost of capital of the company.
The price of the Shares would have been lower if the Pheim (Malaysia) had not given the instructions to purchase the Shares.
The price performance of the Shares against the broader market would have been weaker if Pheim (Malaysia) had not given the instructions to purchase the Shares.

I believe that Pheim (Malaysia)?s orders were not genuine in the sense that: A genuine buyer would not have bought the Shares at the time Pheim (Malaysia) bought.
Given the way share price data is recorded and used by investors, year end closing prices are particularly important in determining portfolio performances.
Moreover, trading volumes at the end of the year also tend to be relatively low.
Despite this, Pheim (Malaysia) aggressively bought stock in the last three market days of 2004.
Pheim (Malaysia) dominated the market for the Shares during the Relevant Period accounting for some 59%, 100% and 98% of all trades on the 29, 30 and 31 December 2004, respectively (see Point 13(a)).
Furthermore Pheim (Malaysia) did not buy at the cheapest price during this period (see Point 13(b)) and the bulk of its orders were placed near the close of each day (see Points 13(b) & (c)).
This should be contrasted with the careful trades and downward trend in the buying price prior to December 2004.
A genuine buyer would not have bought the Shares in the manner in which they were bought.

A genuine buyer of a significant amount of shares, in a thinly traded security, would normally spread their purchases over a longer period of time and over the course of a day so as to minimize the upward impact on the purchase price of the shares and to minimize Share price volatility.

It difficult to believe that a genuine buyer would place all or a significant portion of large orders some 16 minutes, 35 minutes and 10 minutes prior to market close on the 29, 30 and 31 December 2004, respectively (see Point 13(b) & (c)), as Pheim (Malaysia) did.
I am of the opinion that Pheim (Malaysia)?s actions caused an upward spike in the price of the Shares during the Relevant Period.
I am of the opinion that Pheim (Malaysia)?s actions meant its fund did not buy the Shares at the lowest possible price.

I am of the opinion that Pheim (Malaysia)?s actions increased the Share price volatility of UET and that this increase Share price volatility could or would have been to the detriment to both the fund (increases its portfolio risk profile) and to UET (increases its long term cost of capital).
A genuine buyer would not have bought the Shares at the price they were bought.

Given the size of Pheim (Malaysia) trades and the generally thin market liquidity, a genuine buyer of a significant amount of shares, in a thinly traded security, would normally take any opportunity to acquire a large block of shares from another shareholder, either ?off? or ?on? the market, rather than buying from the market as it significantly reduces the risk of the buyer not getting enough shares or paying more for the shares desired.

Where a broker is asked to trade with ?careful discretion?, what is generally understood by ?careful discretion?
?Careful discretion? is a discretionary order that is given to a broker subject to the condition that the broker executes the order in a ?careful? manner.
A discretionary order allows the broker to decide when to buy or sell a share and at what price.
It is an implied term that the broker will do the best for the client.
Careful in the context of careful discretion requires the broker to act carefully and in practice this means that the broker is to perform no worse than the market average.

For example if you gave the broker careful discretion to buy 100,000 shares and only 200,000 shares traded on that day with an volume weighted price of say $1.00, then you would not expect the whole of the 100,000 order to have been bought (the broker will continue to work your deal the following day) and you would expect your average price would be $1.00 or less.
Brokers are not meant to set high closing prices or high prices of any sort when exercising careful discretion.
Careful discretion is normally given for a wide window of time and may include several Trading Days.
It is an oxymoron to give a careful discretion order for 10 minutes or even half an hour.

If the broker in the present case had on the respective days been instructed by the client to carry out the transactions in UET shares with ?careful discretion?, whether the broker exceeded the authority granted to him by purchasing the UET shares in the manner that he did?
As noted in Point 20, it is a nonsense to speak of giving a broker careful discretion when a broker has very little time in which to execute.

You will note that in Table 4 the longest time provided to the broker was on the 30 December 2004 and was 2 hours and 37 minutes prior to market close, which is a very short time to execute 210,000 shares or more than the total volume of the previous 12 Trading Days prior to the Relevant Period.
On the other two days the broker was provided 16 minutes and 10 minutes prior to market close.

As noted in Table 3, the purchases undertaken on behalf of Pheim (Malaysia) drove the price of the Shares: from a day low of 37 cents to a day high of 41 cents and to the day close at 41 cents on the 29 December 2004; from a day low of 40 cents to a day high of 45.5 cents and to day close at 45.5 cents on the 30 December 2004; and from a day low of 35 cents to a day high of 44.5 cents and to the day close at 44.5 cents on the 31 December 2004.
This is a staggeringly gross breach of a careful discretion order.
It was a staggeringly gross breach on the 29 December 2004.

Label: Reason
